title: (x) Soft monolinear tech sans - several alternatives {Stephen}
content:
Hey all,

Now and then I stumble upon these beatiful strokefonts that are used in somewhat older printed matter, I’ve attached a .pdf. Does anybody know where these fonts have their origins? I do know that in old versions of AutoCad there were strokefonts, but maybe anybody knows if there is a program that used this specific font?

Thanks in advance!

Thijs.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [HS-785HB.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20080204034739/http:/typophile.com/files/HS-785HB.pdf) | 572.15 KB |

 [‹ (x) Sphere Macro geometric sans - ITC Avant Garde Gothic {Marc O}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080204034739/http:/typophile.com/node/41542 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Gault Millau serif logo - Engravers {Marten F} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080204034739/http:/typophile.com/node/41527 "Go to next forum topic")
author: thijsg

comments.content: I have no experience with CAD programs, but this type reminds me a lot of the soft monolinear letters (often designed by engineers) for routing and stencils. For reference: [Isonorm](http://web.archive.org/web/20080204034739/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=Isonorm) and [DIN 17](http://web.archive.org/web/20080204034739/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/scangraphic/din_17_sb_regular/). More recent interpretations include [Gotham Rounded and Bryant](http://web.archive.org/web/20080204034739/http:/typographica.org/001082.php).
Thank you for your reply and the links!
